comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Lovely photo - it will be your greatest achievement the day you add the two tags "People Identified" and "Location Identified" to this photo!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Sitting here stunned that it's been up for over an hour and nobody has identified it yet! Could this be our new Sandymount Castle (or Mwah Ha Ha as I used to call it)?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Give me time. I've only just seen it, and Beany and Niall haven't shown up yet either.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: My three initial candidates would be Donard (again) or Powerscourt or Glenmacnass. Maybe Glenmalure.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I see the one after it is two women in an unidentified cave. It looks fairly distinctive.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I reckon it must be Glendalough or lower Glenmacnass. It's not craggy enough for the Mournes, and they're the only bits of Wicklow simultanously so rocky and so wooded.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Having said that, there's rhododendrons. That's often a sign of The West in these pictures.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I think so

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] My initial reaction to the two women in unidentified cave was that it was the cave below Blarney Castle. But for that to be the case, the image would have to be "mirrored" somehow. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] I may be letting the above influence me, and combining unobjectively with fact that we have a Cork photographer, but I wonder whether this photo is also (west) Cork. The strange "rams head" rock-formation (or whatever-the-hell-it-is) might spark someone's geo-location lobe. Whatever that formation is, it may have influenced the photographer and subject on their choice of pose/shot.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] I found one cave in the depths of google that if mirrored, could have been it. I can't remember if it was Blarney or somewhere else though. I think you could well be correct.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] In fact, you're definitly right: farm4.staticflickr.com/3319/3235175640_dc194f8a84_o.jpg I think that probably doesn't help much though, as none of the rivers round there are full of big granite boulders. The pictures must not be related. Where are you thinking for the river - Glengarriff?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Looks like Wicklow to me, the Avonmore or Avonbeg.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Surely this gentleman didn't hike cross country for miles in that outfit: he must be near a road, probably a bridge.

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: Neat photo!

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: I'd hazard the guess that its taken on the Dargle River maybe somewhere near the Lovers leap, Enniskerry, Co Wicklow. There are paths along river here. (as Niall says. the subject isn't dressed for a hike.) Hargrave has been at the Dargle in winter.. catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000288788 catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000288793 catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000288787 Robert French busy there too.. www.nli.ie/glassplates/L_CAB/L_CAB_00424.jpg www.nli.ie/glassplates/L_ROY/L_ROY_02141.jpg www.nli.ie/glassplates/L_ROY/L_ROY_02149.jpg

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Could be, though it looks a bit rockier than any other images of the Dargle I found.

comment.author: 61581709@N03
comment._content: Here's a modern photo of the Dargle valley; shows similar amount and type rocks. And rhododendron. I've photos of the river below Lover's Leap that I will seek out... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tonybrierton/8911119192/]

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/61581709@N03] lovely picture/composition. As above, do you have any photos looking downstream? We might get lucky :)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I don't think you'll get an exact match after 100 years - floods move those boulders about.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I remember well the night Hurricane Charley (25th Aug 1986) tore the place apart. The Paddock ponds at Powerscount burst and sent 1000s of tons of water down in one go. www.braywatch.com/Town/Floods.html You'll have to accept that those boulders still exist..........somewhere. :) ... if it's the Dargle at all !!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The only river I found that looked more like it was a brief stretch of Dodder at the bottom of Kippure, but it's nowhere near as accessible to your average casual man in a suit.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
The Dargle is a better match than the Avonmore/Avonbeg I mentioned earlier. If you follow them upstream, by the time they get this small, they are out of deciduous woods into open mountainside/bog.

Also, the gentleman looks dressed for a day trip to Enniskerry rather than a hill waking expidition...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Thank you, one and all! Most convinced by the Dargle, but as we can't stand over that location in a court of law, I'll change the title in our catalogue for the moment by hedging our bets that it "may be the River Dargle"...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/61581709@N03] Thanks for the help as always!
